ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the relationship between gender and machines, representations of automata, the gendering of textile work and feminization of technical labor that would be seen again with telegraphs, telephones, semi-conductors, etc. Was exposed to work of cyberfeminists, etc. Learned about different forms of writing--close analysis, keyword essays, research, etc.
I developed my critical thinking skills.
Learned a lot about the history of machines and technology in relation to people. my Discussion skills definitely were benefited by this class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The students in the class came from a wide variety of backgrounds--film majors, math majors, computer science, art, etc. This lent a wide range of perspectives to class discussion. I thought most of the material on the syllabus was carefully selected and was a worthwhile read. Professor Hirschfeld-Kroen was also a strength, effectively guiding discussion and willing to meet to talk about class material, papers, etc. Liked the in-class viewings in the different screening rooms! Prof was willing to move/adjust things based on student feedback (for example, shift deadlines, some folks incorporated creative elements into their final papers).

Weaknesses: For a writing course, I think it would have been nice to have more of an emphasis on crafting arguments, structuring essays, etc. Maybe a workshop or something similar (I think workshopping essays was originally planned, but had to be cut due to time)? I also would have found a bit of a background in feminist movements helpful (first wave/second/third). Knowing the context and major ideas of a movement might have put more of the readings in context (Prof Hirschfeld-Kroen did a little of this ad-hoc). I think classmates with more of a WGSS background might have had this knowledge, but at the same time, one of the strengths of the course is wide variety of academic disciplines of the students, so a common language/background could be helpful. Maybe optional mini-lecture?
The discussions were incredibly interesting and lively.
The essays were graded very harshly and there was an expectation of knowledge beyond what was taught. That said, very interesting course and engaging Professor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I found the course well-taught and class discussion engaging (there were students from a wide range of academic backgrounds with insightful comments, Prof. Hirschfeld-Kroen led discussion well in my opinion). Readings/films/course material was interesting. There was flexibility in the assignments based on what your interests were. Prof. Hirschfeld-Kroen was receptive to student feedback throughout the course. I'm really glad I took this course!
I absolutely would, and I already have.
Would recommend to anyone who is curious about technology and its impact on people especially women
yes but be prepared for a lot of work
